abstract.para: This section explains HOWTO build most of the TEI format dictionary from a file formatted the same way as a Dictd compliant .dict file. Note, not the index file.

It relies on you laying out your dictionary with a very simple format. You will still have to construct the TEI header section but most of the work will be done for with the actual content of the dictionary.

section.title: The Dictd.dict Format
section.para: If you have any Dictd format dictionaries installed you may of course open one of the dictionary-name.dict.dz files to have a look at the format and contents. You will need the tool called dictunzip to do so but it comes along with the rest of the Dictd tools.
Beyond the Dictd header section you will notice that the file is a text file with a simple and predictable format.

When a Dictd dictionary is built, using the Dictd tools two files are created. One file, the one we are interested in here, the dictionary-name.dict file, contains the data that is displayed on the interface when a user asks for the translation of a word. The second file, the dictionary-name.index file is a listing of the position of everything in the first .dict file. Together they form an indexed database of headwords and translations.Interfaceheadwordstranslations

example.title: The Dictd .index format
example.para: The corresponding .index file is built by the dictfmt tool and looks a little like this:

section.para:
When running from the Dictd (or Serpento) dictionary server these files are matched. strange, things will happen if you edit one with out the other. There is nothing to stop you working on copies though.
database dictd
00-database-info
00-database-short
00-database-url

section.title: Processing your Dictd format file
section.para: Somehow you have your Headwords and related translations written in the simple format described above. You might need to process a spread sheet or a some other document into this format, as there are many many possibilities I can not give you a simple method to do that.

Otherwise you may have an existing Dictd dictionary file or finally you may be starting from scratch. In which case we recommend you you use a template as demonstrated later. If you have many lexicographic, etymological or other information to add to your dictionary we strongly suggest you use a template or a fully fledged XML editor.
Down load the dict2xml.py python script from the Freedict servers at Sourceforge.
Follow the instructions included in the package to install and run with your file.
All you need to do is something like: dict2xml.py -f your-dict-format.dict -o same-working-name and the rest should happen automatically.
Now hopefully all you have to do is markup any extra entries and add the TEI Header information. Please see the Writing TEI and installing TEI sections.
